title: A Survey on World Models Grounded in Acoustic Physical Information
author: Xiaoliang Chen (SoundAI Technology Co., Ltd.), Le Chang (SoundAI Technology Co., Ltd.), Xin Yu (SoundAI Technology Co., Ltd.), Yunhe Huang (SoundAI Technology Co., Ltd.), Xianling Tu (SoundAI Technology Co., Ltd.)
relevance_why: The survey explores advanced methodologies for acoustic world models, which could inform the development of audio-centric applications in Haohe Liu's work, particularly in areas like audio generation and analysis.
background: The paper reviews approaches for building models that utilize acoustic signals to understand and predict physical interactions and environments, enhancing AI's capability to reason about the physical world.
contribution: This survey introduces frameworks leveraging acoustic physical information to enhance world models, achieving improved perceptual accuracy and causal reasoning in AI systems.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous models primarily focused on visual or single-modal sensing which limited their understanding of complex physical interactions.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work bridges acoustic-based representations with physical reasoning, enabling richer environmental simulations and predictions.

key_innovation: Introduces a comprehensive approach for integrating acoustic signals into world models to develop a nuanced understanding of physical environments.
real_world_impact: The frameworks presented could lead to significant advancements in robotics, healthcare, and autonomous driving, enhancing AI systems’ interaction with real-world environments.
limitations: The survey lacks detailed empirical assessments of the discussed methodologies and their practical implementations.

new_terms.Physics-Informed Neural Networks (PINNs): **Physics-Informed Neural Networks (PINNs)** integrate physical laws into neural networks for improved data efficiency and accuracy in scientific modeling.
new_terms.Acoustic Simultaneous Localization and M: **Acoustic SLAM** is a method that uses sound to map environments and localize an agent within them, suitable for scenarios lacking visual information.
